comments.commentBody: It is long overdue.  Now how about Afghanistan?  Korea? Germany? Japan? Italy? Cut some of this world police occupation out of the budget. Focus on developing the technology of war, but, leave where we are no business...
Most of the troops are getting out, but  thousands of mercenaries are being left there.  Not exactly what the headlines are suggesting.

I'm surprised that the President's speech was not reprinted or linked to here.  This was an historic moment and a great speech.  Half of our soldiers have come home from 2 wars.  Aside from the money being saved by the drawdowns, bringing our troops home strengthens our defense.  We've looked weak being stretched so thin and looking weak is dangerous for the US.  Find the speech online and watch it - this one will be remembered.

Finally, some good news from 1600 Pensylvania Ave.
Campaign promise made good on. 3 years too late. Not deserving of a Nobel Peace Prize. Now end the stupid Afghan war and bring everyone home. Rebuilding this country should involve sending all of the Republicans that have blocked any real efforts to Afghanistan and leaving them there for all eternity.

@364 - "Show of Hands, how many people think this has to do with getting re-elected. Obama cares nothing for the troops other than as useful photo props."

And once more, Republicans can't decide what to complain about, only that they MUST complain.

It's either a political ploy, as stated in the above quote above, or, as other Republicans deem it, President Obama's carrying out of what GWB planned all along to occur at this time.

It cannot be both. If you don't like the time frame, go take it up with Bush.

Sheesh.

He's doing it for the votes, he could care less about the military who are only photo props.

Muslim extremists will soon enough control Iraq, but hey votes r votes

In my lifetime, we have gone to war for nothing.
Vietnam
Iraq- twice
Afghanastan-
I won't bother with Grenada, Nicaragua, and the many others.

This country can sing great songs and make great banks, but it can't control the world.

The song writers and bankers need to to come together to make America great again.

Let us dream, once more, of

America for ALL

One point that should be remembered is that it is by no means clear that the average Iraqui is better off thanks to the US invasion. The Northern Kurds certainly are but those who lost their lives (one estimate is that more than one million died) most certainly are not. Sadam was a monster but he was a secularist and the theocracy that is likely to inherit power after US troop leave is going to oppress at least fifty percent of the population, that is to say women.

Spin, spin, spin. The Iraq government *ordered* US troops to leave no later than 12/31/2011. And, in a further slap in the face for the "Obama Doctrine" He guardian is reporting tonight that the Iraq government refused last minute pleas by the White House to keep open even one US base there. That, in spite of billions of dollars in foreign aid offered if they permitted this. It has all turned to ashes for this pathetic jerk of a President. His trade policies are a failure, his economic and foreign policies are a disaster, he threw his supporters under a bus in favor of easy Wall Street cash, and his poll numbers are circling the drain, heading right down the sewer. Anyone want to bet that this scoundrel isn't even a candidate come April... Of, if he is, he creates the worst election rout for a political party in US history?

President Bush signed an agreement with Iraq called the Status of Forces Agreement on November 27, 2008.  It said that all US troops would be out of the country by the end of 2011.  Nothing to do with Obama keeping a campaign promise which he was supposed to keep soon after taking office.  He's taking credit where none is due as usual.

Best thing Obama has done as President...hoped he would do it sooner (like he promised). But credit given. We gave Iraq a chance to remake their nation at incredible cost to ourselves. But we can't stay there forever and as a Republican I am appalled at the reaction of the 'candidates'. Enough. But quit crowing Democrats. All your leaders voted for this war so quit trying to pretend you are somehow unsullied by it all.

This started as a border skirmish between Kuwait and Iraq and the Bushes' fixation with Saddam. Called off at the gates of Baghdad then restarted again without provocation. Civil war in Iraq may follow. All combatants will be armed to the teeth with what the U.S. leaves behind. Bloody. Oh what those thieves in Kuwait started.

It's about time to abscond Iraq completely, for George W. Bush caused this country to lose so many lives, together with loss of limbs and massive mental or psychological problems. I refuse to go along with the notion that a war existed, for it represented a gross act of military adventurism, together with a means by some to collect massive profits at the expense of lives and an absolute and despicable waste of resources. We had no business attempting to keep even one (1) American in Iraq with the silly and perverted idea that immunity should be granted to such American. We must not leave one (1) American in Iraq, for it shall be an integral ally of Iran before the close of this year.
It appears that America has given Iran a complete gift without any strings attached thereto. America was duly had in Iraq and that, indeed, is a profound tragedy.

I have been trying to make Iraq a distant memory, but the president's announcement today was welcome news. I had just about given up on him. After spending the last year in Iraq, I was privy to a lot of what happened behind the scenes, and none of it looked too good for any of us. Al Sadr and Maleki already made their deals in late 2010 to have us out by the end of this year. That was not very well publicized.

All the coalition soldiers and contractors and other civilians have been put in more danger because of these backroom deals, but they accepted it. After all, it is a war zone. I remember the rockets, the mortars and the gunfire, and I traveled all over that country, from the Kurdish north and the Syrian border to the Iranian border east of Basra. 27 places in all. A lot more than most. But I never stepped outside the wire, unless it was on a helo, convoy or fixed wing. Fly to the next place. The work I did helped keep us safe, but thanks to the decisions of the Iraqi government, I saw each week's report detail a further degeneration of the safety for our troops and, of course, for the rest of us. The regional commanders made a lot of the decisions that put us at risk. It was not the president.

I, for one, am glad Obama is pulling out every last one of the soldiers. If the Iraqi army needs more training after all the efforts we made (and I saw plenty), they better call fast, because now their calls will have to be made to the operators of the new world for the military industrial corporations. Frankly, I hope they don't call. I'm retiring. No more war, thank you.

Good move to bring American Military Forces back home to shut down the war in Iraq.  I will never forget GWB, joking around in the Oval Office by looking under his desk for WMD.  Now, POTUS, calling for the troops to be home by the end of the year.  I recall hearing that Exxon Iraq won 8 contracts earlier this year.  The Iraq conflict began and ended with oil; WMD was a lie perpetrated on U.S., taxpayers by GWB and Cheney.  I'm not duped by pols, or how far they will go to win reelection.  The reality is high unemployment, jobless Americans, poorer Americans since President Obama was elected.

Regardless of prosecutorial success, the Attorney General, Mr. Holder, should immediately seek indictments against George W. Bush, Cheney, Rumsfeld, Pearl, Wolfowitz and all other neocons who inspired George W. Bush to invade Iraq and seek non-existing weapons of mass destruction. Join all of them and let such people convince an honourable court that they were not responsible for such stupid folly. As far as I am supremely convinced, they should all be incarcerated.

"Hey, right on GWB's schedule! with the exception that GWB would have made the decision based on the facts on the ground rather than re-election."

You might want to check your facts. The withdrawal schedule was originally *Obama's* idea. After he proposed it publicly, the Iraqis embraced it, and Bush, who had been insisting on a longer stay, caved in.

#364 Taxicab says: "...Obama cares nothing for the troops...".
I respectfully disagree -- he's saving their lives, and he uses drones as much as possible to minimize casualties. Bush, a draft dodger like Cheney the warprofiteer, and Rove, sent 4000+ of our troops to die, by starting a full-scale boots-on-the-ground unnecessary war of choice, based on lies.

Thank you!! Mr President, for having the courage and grace to bring the troops home!Of course the Republicans and those who profit from wars will be unhappy. The republicans would rather die than give credit for a job well done!! Foreign policy which included broad support from all countries involved is a big step forward.

Now that President Obama is ending one of George W. Bush's two wars paid for "off the books," maybe the hundreds of billions spent rebuilding Iraq will be redirected to rebuilding our own country. How can Americans hold our heads up when the news reports that foreigners are buying up homes in this country that Americans can't afford to hold onto? And with tens of millions more Americans now losing health insurance allegedly provided by employers? This country is seriously broken and it's high time we focus on fixing it.

I want to thank President Obama for finally putting an end to this war at the end of the year, but I also want to thank the Iraqi government for kicking us out. Without the determination of the Iraqis to get us out, the war mongering factions here would have made it very difficult for the President to withdraw all troops. I assume Charles Krauthammer is sulking somewhere right now.

Thank Goodness that someone finally puts an end to this thankless war.  This was a war for oil from the beginning.  It belongs in the history books. Well done Mr. President.  Mr. Obama has done a great job considering the total mess that was left for him.  I for one will continue to support him.  I only hope that the congress and senate figure out that this country is not only a play ground for the rich, but a home for 350 million people.

The war in Iraq really ended on September 12, 2006, the day after our 5 year anniversary of 911.  That is the date that Nouri Al-Maliki, the prime minister of Iraq made his first official visit to Tehran. During a meeting with Ahmadinejad who is the enemy of our country it was decided that they would resolve their differences and the two countries would form a partnership that would share the development of the riches oil fields in the world which lay on the border between the two countries. The question was raised about United States occupation of Iraq. Both parties agreed that they did not need to anything but simply let the United States stay in Iraq until December 31, 2011 when the occupation of Iraq was set to expire according to the contract made by George W. Bush. The renewal of this contract would be non-negotiable. The news of this agreement was in newspapers and media around the world but received little if any attention in the United States.  Very few oil contracts were issued to US companies to develop this oil.  At least one oil company was told that they would have to have permission from Iran in order to to secure a contract for development.  Just Google a few of the keywords and you can still find many of the news stories on the Internet.

When President Obama said, "After nearly nine years, America's war in Iraq will be over," he revealed more than he intended. The war in Iraq will be over because the U.S. has decided it is over. There is no formal signing of papers between two enemy countries to show the surrender of one and a declaration of victory by the other. There was only one party to this war--the U.S. It decided to have a war with Iraq--poisoned its environment, destroyed its infrastructure, and left millions of Iraqis displaced and dead. Now it will go practice using all that neat military equipment somewhere else, maybe Iran.

To Hank #140 'My book roughly estimated the price of a human life at $10 million, and considering it was penned by Greg Mankiw that's probably a low estimate. But if we take that number for what it is, we get: $10 million x (4,400 American soldiers + 103,100 Iraqi citizens) = $1,075,000,000,000 or $1.075 trillion.'

That overlooks the fact that the value of human life varies according to its distance from America. For example, for the price of a pizza, you could probably save the life of one Bangladeshi child or something by contributing to a charity concerning itself with -- say -- water filtration systems.

However, you'll get the pizza. You would even resent it if the government proposed taking away your pizza money for the purpose discussed.

Your text's calculations probably assumed it was an AMERICAN life that was in question. That might be worth ten million dollars. On the other hand, a Greek life, for example, might be worth two million. An Iraqi life? Maybe five hundred dollars.

So we get $10 million x 4,400 American soldiers + $500 x 103,100 Iraqi citizens) = $44,051,550,000 or about $44 billion.'

Still not peanuts, but hardly the most significant component of the cost of the war.

Unless of course you happen to be one of the Iraqis in question. These things are subjective.
